channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #118 - Do we â™¥ Unicode?
item.description:
Hi,

lots of great articles this week. Way too many! And many of them have all kinds of funny Unicode characters in their title or description. Let's see if the Perl Weekly can already handle those? If you see any breakage, please let me know!

(Actually I got an exception from Encode during the conversion and Carp::Always helped me locate the source of the problem. See article below.

Enjoy!

item.title: We're Hiring Perl Software Developers - Grant Street Group
item.description:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume: 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com

item.title: Back-End Blacksmith
item.description: Do you take pride in your craft and want to have fun() at the same time? Are you a geek? Join the team of iwantmyname from anywhere.

item.title: Cluj.pm community members get together again
item.description: On 7 November 2013 in Cluj-Napoca, Romania with ribasushi (aka. Peter Rabbitson), SawyerX, Attila-Mihaly Balazs, Mihai Pop and you!

item.title: Â¡Viva Perl!: Official Announcement of the Call for Speakers
item.description: In cast that was not clear from the title, this is the first Call for Speakers of YAPC::NA that will be held in Orlando, Florida between 23â€“25th June.

item.title: Carton Talks in Europe
item.description: Tatsuhiko Miyagawa is doing hiw world tour, (limited edition) and will speak in Copenhagen and London, and he is also ready to drink beer in Frankfurt.

item.title: Pragmatic Perl Interview (English Translation)
item.description: An interview with chromatic, the author of the Modern Perl book

item.title: How I manage my Perl distributions
item.description: There are some large Perl-based applications out there that use their own way of packaging and distributing the code, but Steven Haryanto belives it is better to use the same toolchain as is used for CPAN distributions. Even if the application does not end up on CPAN. Even if it is an in-house or other proprietary application. (I tend to agree.) In this article he describes how he handles the process.

item.title: How to use the debugger with Moose
item.description: I have been a long-time fan of the command line debugger that comes with Perl, but in certain cases, especially when using Moose, it has issues. Now Ovid shows a solution using DB::Skip written by Christian Walde.

item.title: Dist::Zilla â™¥ encoding
item.description: Last weekend there was a mini hackathon at Ricardo Signes' house. David Golden tells us about the imprvements they made to Dist::Zilla and which plugins might need further work in order to make sure everything works fine with UTF-8.

item.title: Parallel DNS lookups using AnyEvent
item.description: An explanation and a full example script by Sebastian Willing.

item.title: Acme-oop-ism Part Two: Type::Tiny
item.description: As Toby Inkster explains: 'Acme-oop-ism is about writing code that works in Moose, Mouse and Moo.' His work allows the deprecation of several modules in favour of one that can handle all 3 OOP systems.

item.title: How to redirect and restore STDOUT
item.description: Perltricks by David Farrell

item.title: Enable Backtraces with Carp::Always (Modern Perl Tips)
item.description: This module will attach a stack-trace to every warning and exception, without modifying the code!

item.title: modules seeking homes
item.description: Ricardo Signes tries to sell some of his CPAN modules.

item.title: CPAN modules for converting markdown to HTML
item.description: Just as I am going to need one, Neil Bowers went over 9 CPAN modules converting Markdown to HTML. I love these comparisions, but it also somehow disturbs me. Frankly in many cases I'd just would like to be told 'use this' and not need to think about it much.

item.title: POD Web View
item.description: A fun web application written by MichaÅ‚ Wojciechowski using Perl Dancer. You type in some POD (or upload a file or give it a URL) and it will convert it to HTML and show it in search.cpan.org style, or MetaCPAN style, or GitHub style.

item.title: Ruling the world with Perl and Excel
item.description: brian d foy shows how to create manager and executive friendly reports. (aka. Excel files with colors.)

item.title: Plotly - Scientific Graphing Libraries
item.description: It says on the web page: 'Modern, drop-in alternatives for matplotlib, ggplot2, and MATLAB plotting routines with the added bonus of interactive, web-ready output.' Go try it!

item.title: Perl DBD::ODBC 1.44_4 released to the CPAN
item.description: This is a development releases, but as Martin Evans writes this is going to be 1.45. So if you depend on DBD::ODBC, you'd better test it. See changes in the latest development versions.

item.title: Parsing JSON with a single Regex
item.description: brian d foy explains the crazy regex written by Randal Schwartz to the Houston Perl Mongers and to all of us.

item.title: Exception to Rule
item.description: Bruce Gray (Util) gave a presentation about error handling with and without throwing exceptions at YAPC::NA 2013.

item.title: TWiki-6.0.0 Released - Better Usability, Scalability & App Platform
item.description: With shiny new dashboard and lots of other new features. In case you don't know, Twiki, is one of the oldes and probably the largest Perl-based wiki.

item.title: Perl Catalyst 'Hamburg' Development Release 4 on CPAN
item.description: Thank to John Napiorkowski we have regular reporting in the development of the Catalyst web framework. Several improvements especially in the area of better PSGI support to enable mounting other PSGI based applications inside a Catalyst app.

item.title: Writing Non-Blocking Applications with Mojolicious: Part 1
item.description: Joel Berger starts the series of articles by asking the question: 'Why should I chose Mojolicious versus one of the other major Perl web frameworks?'. His point is that just as Node.js, Mojolicious was also designed non-blocking in mind. He then goes ahead and shows two versions of a pastebin application.

item.title: Perl 6 changes - 2013W43
item.description: 'Flip flops can be negated.' - I wonder, does that mean it will first flop?

item.title: YE2013 & PPW2013 Survey Results online
item.description: Barbie has posted the results and wrote some explanation.

item.title: Austrian Perl Workshop
item.description: November 2-3, 2013, Salzburg, Austria

item.title: YAPC::Brazil 2013
item.description: November 15-16, 2013, Curitiba, PR, Brazil

item.title: Nordic Perl Workshop 2013
item.description: November 23, 2013, Copenhagen, Denmark

item.title: London Perl Workshop (LPW 2013)
item.description: Saturday 30th November 2013 at Westminster University
